block.p: Five years ago, J. K. Rowling, a struggling, single mother in Edinburgh, completed a children's novel, written mostly in coffee shops. Today ''Harry Potter'' is the biggest publishing phenomenon in history.

''Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone'' and two sequels, all about an orphaned boy with wizard powers, have sold nearly 21 million copies. The fourth book -- ''Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire'' -- is being published with the kind of hoopla reserved for the Super Bowl.

Five years ago, J. K. Rowling, a struggling, single mother in Edinburgh, completed a children's novel, written mostly in coffee shops. Today ''Harry Potter'' is the biggest publishing phenomenon in history.

''Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone'' and two sequels, all about an orphaned boy with wizard powers, have sold nearly 21 million copies. The fourth book -- ''Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire'' -- is being published with the kind of hoopla reserved for the Super Bowl.

The book was published yesterday, when a record first printing of 3.8 million copies went on sale in the United States. Scholastic Inc., released the book at 12:01 a.m., and bookstores around the nation gave midnight ''Harry Potter'' parties, with clerks dressed as wizards and witches.
''People have been excited about this for months,'' said Barbara Theroux, owner of the Fact and Fiction Bookstore in Missoula, Mont.

Despite the extraordinary secrecy with which the book was published, newspapers report that several lucky children in Virginia received early copies. An 8-year-old girl in Fairfax got one from a clerk who apparently didn't realize the book was embargoed, and a Richmond Wal-Mart store mistakenly sold 20 copies before the book was pulled from the shelves.
To the delight of Scholastic and Warner Brothers, which owns the movie rights, Ms. Rowling has promised three more ''Harry Potter'' books before the series concludes.
